stream_context.summary: Kaze works on Course 14, showing an off-stream crayon-drawing mechanic, prototyping a new paper-spring object, and brainstorming a snow-biome section where Luigi loses his crayon.

development_findings.summary: A functional crayon mechanic now lets the player draw on a star; colouring it awards the Power Star and Kaze plans a sound effect and a palette swap that turns the crayon blue after collection.
development_findings.quote: When the crayon star is collected, make the crayon blue.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejected texture filtering for the HUD after testing because it made numbers look smeared and inconsistent with the original SM64 aesthetic.
The existing Styrofoam-mountain geometry for the area looked "terrible," so Kaze will rebuild that section from scratch.
He began modelling a ‘paper spring’—a folded-paper platform that compresses and launches Mario—but struggled with the folding geometry and opted to prototype from the bottom up in Blender.
development_findings.quote: This is deceptively a lot more complicated than it looks.

development_findings.summary: Paper-spring physics were implemented with squash-and-stretch and then tuned to feel ‘predictable’ rather than physically perfect by raising damping and reducing oscillation.
development_findings.quote: Those are great spring physics. They look realistic, but they're fudged enough to make this work.

development_findings.summary: A general-purpose sliding function now controls multiple interactive objects, part of an effort to build reusable code instead of single-use behaviours.

The snow biome’s gameplay loop: pick up Luigi’s lost crayon, navigate obstacles, return to Luigi. Kaze is seeking ways to make the return trip feel like a journey (buttons, breakable crates, invisible platforms that appear when painted).
He is considering invisible platforms that become visible only after the player ‘draws’ over them with the yellow crayon, taking inspiration from Drawn to Life/Scribblenauts.
Ideas for snow visuals include cotton-like white material, animated e-mapped hexagon particles for falling snow, and ‘foam-toothpick snowmen’ that could act as enemies.
The hidden ‘bit pipe’ entrance may be moved to a more visible spot and possibly disguised inside a ribbon-wrapped gift model.
There will be no 100-coin stars; difficulty is being kept moderate and accessible, with optional self-imposed movement challenges encouraged.
Kaze plans a decal overlay system so Mario can appear splattered with oil, dirt, etc., rather than swapping entire models.
He is re-evaluating the Star-Collection screen; wants animation and personality but ‘not Cocomelon’ levels of flash.
Certain enemies (e.g., thimble guys) now drop five coins to aid coin routing.

context_findings.summary: It was Kaze’s birthday; Zeina bought him a cake and made chocolate milk, and chat repeatedly congratulated him.
Kaze argues that excessive difficulty can be an accessibility issue; real fun comes from freedom to attempt optional, self-imposed challenges.
context_findings.quote: Freedom is the ability to do things without a penalty.

context_findings.summary: He wants future levels to feel more ‘schizophrenic,’ citing Hazy Maze Cave’s random elements and concluding that unexpected connections make spaces memorable.
context_findings.quote: You kind of just need to be schizophrenic and make connections that don't actually exist in your levels.

context_findings.summary: Frustration surfaced while trying to model the paper spring geometry, though he expressed clear satisfaction once the physics felt right.
He joked about courting a Nintendo cease-and-desist for marketing hype and tweeted Nintendo asking for legal rights to SM64.
Dismissed new social network BlueSky as unlikely to succeed due to network-effect economics.
context_findings.quote: Blue Sky doesn't really exist yet, and it's never going to exist.

biobak.summary: Entered chat, offered birthday wishes and light humour (“90 % of gamblers quit right before they win”), but no concrete development tasks this stream.

zeina.summary: Bought a birthday cake and prepared chocolate milk for Kaze, showing personal support during the stream.

key_stories.title: Crayon mechanic revelation
key_stories.summary: Off-stream, Kaze built a system that lets Mario pick up a crayon and literally draw on a Power Star. Showing it live, he noted it needs audio and colour feedback.
key_stories.challenge: Implement freehand drawing on N64 hardware within SM64’s engine.
key_stories.process: Created marker input, star texture overlay, and collision to grant the star when colouring is complete.
key_stories.outcome: Working prototype demonstrated; next steps include sound and colour change.
key_stories.key_quote: Look at this cool thing I added off stream. You can draw with a marker, and if you color the star, you get a star.

key_stories.title: Paper spring struggle
key_stories.summary: Kaze tried to model a folded-paper spring but found the geometry unexpectedly hard. He iterated in Blender and then coded physics until the bounce felt right.
key_stories.challenge: Model believable folded-paper geometry that doesn’t self-intersect and behaves like a spring.
key_stories.process: Sketched with paper, built a bottom-up mesh in Blender, wrote physics with squash-and-stretch, tweaked damping.
key_stories.outcome: Acceptable spring behaviour achieved; still needs visual polish.
key_stories.key_quote: This is deceptively a lot more complicated than it looks.

key_stories.title: Course 14 snow-biome rethink
key_stories.summary: Unhappy with previous Styrofoam mountains, Kaze decided to scrap and redesign the entire snowy section, aiming for a ‘journey’ where Mario recovers Luigi’s crayon.
key_stories.challenge: Old geometry looked bad and gameplay was too linear.
key_stories.process: Deleted terrain, brainstormed cotton snow, foam-snowmen enemies, buttons, breakable boxes, invisible platforms triggered by drawing.
key_stories.outcome: No final layout yet, but clear design pillars (journey, drawing-based gates) were set.
key_stories.key_quote: I want bringing the crayon back to be a challenge… I want this to be a little bit of a journey.

key_stories.title: Philosophical pivot toward randomness
key_stories.summary: While rating SM64 levels for ‘placeness,’ Kaze realised Hazy Maze Cave’s random elements made it memorable and decided future levels should embrace similar unpredictability.
key_stories.challenge: Levels felt too logical and connected.
key_stories.process: Analyzed Hazy Maze Cave, concluded random associations like Dorrie make spaces interesting, resolved to add more ‘schizophrenic’ design.
key_stories.outcome: Design guideline established for upcoming areas.
key_stories.key_quote: We should just be more schizophrenic and make connections that don't exist.
